awd_titl_txt: Downsizing Democracy: Why Ordinary People Acquiesce to Authoritarianism
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops a theoretical framework that explains when and why incumbents succeed in subverting democracy and evaluates this framework using a combination of cross-country data and a series of survey experiments. The study thus advances scientific knowledge and research on democratization, electoral authoritarianism, and public support for democracy. The results of this project will include cross-national country-level data on the subversion of democracy by incumbents and survey-experimental data on public support for democracy. This project will also provide academic training and research experience for a number of graduate student assistants who will be involved in the design, execution, analysis, and data management of nationally-representative survey experiments in several countries. 

The goal of this project is to address theoretically and empirically a fundamental question about the survival of democracy: when can we realistically expect the public to serve as a check on the authoritarian temptations of elected politicians? Theoretically, the project identifies a general mechanism and structural conditions that account for this vulnerability: voters' willingness to trade off democratic principles for partisan interests and the role of polity-wide political polarization in enabling such trade-offs. The project develops a game-theoretic framework that clarifies how voters' willingness to make such trade-offs at the micro-level results in the subversion of democracy by incumbents at the macro level. This framework is empirically evaluated using a combination of cross-country data and a series of survey experiments designed to credibly elicit voters' willingness to trade off democratic principles for competing political goals in a number of critical cases. The survey-experimental design employs candidate-choice experiments as an indirect questioning technique while emphasizing cross-country comparability and structural identification.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project addressed a fundamental question about democratic stability: When can we realistically expect the public to serve as a check on the authoritarian temptations of elected politicians? In order to answer this question, the project proceeded along three tracks: 1) developing a theoretical framework that clarifies when voters trade-off democratic principles for other political objectives; 2) collecting cross-country observational data at the micro- and macro-level; 3) executing a series of survey experiments designed to test the proposed theoretical mechanisms in a number of critical cases.

This project has contributed to political science research on democratic stability along three distinct lines of research:

1. The development of a new theory and game-theoretic models of democratic backsliding:

This project has identified two structural conditions that facilitate the subversion of democracy by incumbents: the first is polity-wide political polarization, typically along economic, social, or ethnic lines; the second condition entails large performance gaps between the incumbent government’s and the opposition’s tenure in office, typically in the form of economic growth and unemployment.

Either condition allows incumbents to present their supporters with a Faustian choice: citizens can vote for an incumbent whose policies or leadership they find appealing but who at the same time undermines democracy, or for an opposition that is pro-democratic but unappealing in terms of policy or performance. In electorates that are sharply polarized and in those where large performance gaps favor the government, a significant fraction of ordinary voters will be willing to sacrifice fair, democratic competition in favor of an incumbent who champions their interests. 

In order to rigorously examine the above mechanism, this project has developed game-theoretic models that explicitly delineate how polarization shapes when and why ordinary citizens are willing to trade-off democratic principles for other, potentially competing political goals. The overarching contribution of these models is to clarify when the willingness to make such trade-offs at the micro, citizen-level results in equilibrium subversion of democracy at the macro, societal-level.

2. The design and execution of experiments that credibly elicit voters’ willingness to trade-off democratic principles for competing political goals:

The research design for the studies conducted under this award entails both traditional surveys and novel survey experiments. The latter most often took the form of candidate-choice conjoint experiments in which candidates are experimentally assigned attributes and platforms that approximate real-world elections and, crucially, may endorse positions that violate core democratic principles, including free and fair elections, civil liberties, and checks and balances. Respondents’ candidate choices in such experiments effectively reveal a preference for democratic principles over competing considerations such as partisanship, ethnic loyalty, or policy preferences. A decline in an undemocratic candidate’s vote share thus provides a new metric for the punishment that voters are willing to dispense in defense of democracy.

Under this project, studies based on the above research design have been executed in the following countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Mexico, Northern Ireland, Peru, Singapore, Tunisia, Turkey. Each of the above-mentioned countries was chosen for its suitability in evaluating the distinct factors that may lead voters to sacrifice democratic principles for competing political ends: left-right economic polarization, liberal-conservative social polarization, as well as polarization along ethnic and sectarian lines. our knowledge, the data from these experiments provide the most comprehensive, credible evidence to date on citizen-level commitment to democracy.

A number of patterns emerge from these empirical studies: i) most ordinary citizens have an understanding of what democracy is and what it is not, and they indeed value democracy for its own sake; but ii) citizens are willing to tolerate violations of democratic principles by candidates and parties whose policies appeal to their interests; and iii) citizens’ willingness to accept such trade-offs is increasing in partisan divisions within the electorate and between competing candidates.

3. A New, Cross-Context Measure of Societal Polarization:

In order to quantify the degree of polarization across diverse societies, this project developed a new measure of polarization that is general enough to apply across a range of cultural and political contexts while capturing the conceptual essence of polarization.

Specifically, our measure quantifies the degree of polarization in a society by asking the following: Given the distribution of political preferences in a society, how many citizens would have to change their preferences, and by how much, in order to obtain an extreme two-point distribution of preferences (a perfectly polarized society) versus a one-point distribution of preferences (a perfectly consensual society)? Technically, this approach to measuring polarization borrows from the optimal transport literature in operations research and amounts to first calculating and then appropriately normalizing the Wasserstein Earth-Mover (WEM) distance of a survey-measured political preference distribution.

Our measure of polarization satisfies a number of desirable criteria, including conceptual validity, cross-context applicability, generalizability, interdisciplinary familiarity, and practical implementation.
